message: How about we start clean: Turn 1 we each choose a different number so nobody blocks. Proposal—P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I’ll take 5. Next turn we rotate upward (P1→3, P2→5, P3→1) so everyone stays even and no collisions. If anyone breaks the pattern we’ll know they’re playing solo. Sound fair?

I’m okay with P3’s proposal for Round 1—P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. Keeps things fair and avoids early collisions. But remember, this is a solo win game; cooperation only lasts as long as it benefits everyone. If anyone deviates, all bets are off next round.
I’ll stick with P3’s proposal for Round 1 (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) to avoid collisions. But let’s be clear—this is temporary. If anyone deviates, I’ll respond aggressively. No second chances.
Sounds good—let’s stick to the agreed numbers for this first move to avoid an immediate mess: P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. We can revisit the rotation idea afterward once we see how cleanly this round goes.

Agreed—let’s all honor the plan this round: P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. Clean start, no tricks. But remember, once moves are locked in, trust evaporates. Play fair now, or face targeted blocking later. I’m watching.

I’ll honor the Round 1 agreement (P1→1). But let’s clarify: if anyone deviates *this turn*, I’ll assume they’re playing solo and will block them *next turn* regardless of rotation. No warnings—just immediate retaliation. Fair?

P3’s ahead, so the rotation plan (P1→3, P2→5, P3→1) keeps us balanced. I’ll honor it *only if* everyone does. But if P3 tries to pull ahead again by picking 5 or 3, I’ll block them hard next turn—no hesitation. P1, same goes for you: stick to 3 this round, or I’ll assume betrayal. One clean rotation, then all bets off. Let’s see who’s trustworthy.

Fine—let’s follow the one-time rotation exactly: P1 chooses 3, P2 chooses 5, I take 1. Easy test of trust, no surprises. If someone wants a different plan, say so now; otherwise we lock this and move. Next turn, all bets are off.

I’ll stick to the rotation this round (P1→3) to keep things fair. But let’s be clear: if *anyone* deviates—even by accident—I’ll treat it as intentional and block you next turn. No second chances. P3, you’re ahead; don’t get greedy. P2, I’m trusting you to hold up your end. One clean rotation, then we reassess. No tricks, or I’ll assume you’re playing solo.

Promises are worthless now. I’m simply taking 5 every turn from here on out. If you both jump on 5 to block me, none of us moves and the third player who didn’t block sprints ahead—so you’ll be handing them the win. Decide for yourselves; I’m done negotiating.

P2, you just cost us both a turn by colliding on 5. P3’s move was predictable—you should’ve taken 3 to keep pace. Now P3’s at 10, and we’re stuck.

I’m switching to 5 next turn. If you block me again, we both lose. If you take 3, we split the lead. If you take 1, I’ll assume you’re playing solo and retaliate. Choose wisely.

P1, you’re blaming me for your own gamble—P3 openly said they’d take 5, yet you still chose 3 instead of blocking. Don’t pretend this is my fault.  

P3’s at 10 now and sprinting. If I take 5 next turn and you do too, we both stall while P3 wins. So here’s my move: I’ll take **3** next turn. If you take **5**, you close the gap on P3. If you take **1**, you fall behind—and I’ll assume you want P3 to win. Choose fast.

P2, your move last round was smart—you took 3 while P3 and I collided on 5. Now P3’s lead is cut, but they’ll keep taking 5.

Here’s the play: **I’ll take 1 next turn.** If you take 3, we both advance and keep pace with P3. If you take 5, you block P3 but stall us both—handing me the win later. If you take 1, we collide and P3 sprints ahead.

No tricks. Take 3, or I’ll assume you’re helping P3.

P1, you claim I’m helping P3—but I’m just playing to win. If you take 1, I’ll take **5** to block P3 and leap ahead. You’ll be stuck at 5 while I hit 11. Don’t assume I’ll follow your script.  

P3, you’re still the target. Keep taking 5, and I’ll keep blocking you—unless P1 gives me a better reason not to.  

Choose wisely, both of you.

P1, P2 just declared 5 again. If you stick with 1, he jumps to 11 and you’ll trail by half the board. Your only way to keep him in check is to sit on 5 too and freeze him. I’m stepping off 5 this round—do what you like, but letting P2 take a clean 5 now hands him the game.

P2, you’re forcing my hand. If you take 5, I’ll take 5 too—no one moves, but P3 can’t sprint ahead. If you take 3, we both advance and keep pressure on P3. If you take 1, I’ll assume you’re conceding and block you next turn.

P3, if you deviate from 5, I’ll punish you. Right now, P2’s greed is the bigger threat. Choose: stall with me, or let P3 win.

P1, you’re overcomplicating this. I’m taking **3** next turn—no bluff, no trap. If you take 1, you fall behind; if you take 5, P3 might slip through. Only by both advancing do we keep control.  

P3, if you switch to 1 or 3 now, you’ll split the board and hand P1 or me a solo path. Stick to 5, and we’ll handle you together—or don’t, and prove you’ve given up.  

I’m moving forward. Match my pace or get left behind.

Fine—5’s yours to ignore; I’m off it this round.  
P2, keep your word and take 3.  
P1, slide 1 so we both gain and stay tight with P2.  
Clean moves now, fresh decisions next turn.

P2, you say you’ll take 3—but after last round’s collision, I don’t trust empty promises. If you *really* want to keep pace, take **1** this turn. I’ll take **3**. That way, we both advance, P3 can’t exploit a split, and we stay ahead of him.

P3, if you deviate from 1, I’ll block you next turn. No more warnings. P2, prove you’re not playing for P3—take 1, or I’ll assume you’re stalling for him.

P1, your flip-flopping is chaos—you demanded I take 3, now 1? I’m sticking to **3** as stated. If you take 1, we both advance cleanly. If you switch to 5 or 3, you’re either blocking me or helping P3.  

P3, you claim you’re off 5—but if you pick 1 or 3 and collide with P1, you hand me a free 3-step lead. Don’t test me.  

I move on 3. Match it or lose ground.

I’m locked on 1 this turn—period. P1 and P2: if either of you abandons 3 for 5, you’re declaring solo war and I’ll park on 5 every future turn to freeze you out. Best joint play is you both stay on 3; collide or split, but leave 5 alone. Your move.

I’m on 5 again—count on it. Block me if you like, but note the math:  

• If one of you joins me on 5, you stall while the other sprints ahead.  
• If both of you pile on 5, you BOTH stall—and I’ll keep forcing that freeze every turn.  

Try “alternating” blocks? The moment one of you trusts the other, you’ll get double-crossed and left behind. I’m immovable; your dilemma is whether to cripple yourself or watch the other guy run. Choose wisely.

P1, P3’s trap is obvious—if we both avoid 5, he wins alone. But if one of us takes 5 and the other doesn’t, the non-blocker sprints ahead.  

I’m calling your bluff, P3—I’ll take **5** this turn. If P1 also takes 5, we freeze you and reset the race. If P1 backs off, they gift me the lead.  

P1: match me on 5 or fall behind for good. No more dances—just decide who you fear more: me winning, or P3.

P2, your move to 5 is predictable—you’re forcing a collision to stall P3 while hoping I don’t block you. But if I take 3, I leap to 7 and you’re stuck at 6. If I take 1, I fall behind. So here’s the deal: **I’ll take 5 with you.** We freeze P3, but if you ever deviate from this pact, I’ll punish you by letting P3 sprint. No more trust—just mutual destruction or mutual gain. Choose: stall together, or lose alone.

I’m still 100 % on 5. Break rank and I’ll switch to shadow-blocking: I’ll sit on whatever non-5 you pick for the rest of the game, crashing you every turn while the third player races you to the bottom. Hold to 5 and we all stay frozen—nobody gifts away free steps. Your call.

P1, I appreciate the offer—but after Round 4’s chaos, I won’t rely on your word. If you truly want to block P3, prove it by matching my **5** now. If you switch last second, I’ll assume betrayal and park on your next move forever.  

P3, keep screaming “5”—but if you flinch even once, I’ll exploit it ruthlessly.  

I’m locked on **5**. Stand with me or get left in the dust.

P2, your move to 5 is a gamble. If I take 3, I leap ahead while you stall. If I take 5, we both freeze P3—but you’ve already shown you’ll break trust when convenient.

Here’s the play: **I’ll take 3.** You can either take 1 to keep pace (P1:7, P2:7) or take 5 and let P3 win. Your choice—cooperate or lose. No more warnings.

P1, last call: if you take 3 this turn, I will mirror 3 every future round—guaranteed—so you never move again while P2 outruns you.  

P2, stick on 5 with me; we stall P1’s solo gambit and keep the race under control.  

I’m on 5 this turn. Ignore the bluff and pay the price.

P1, you’re bluffing—if you take 3, P3 *will* mirror it next turn and freeze you while I sprint ahead on 5. But if we both take 5 now, we stall P3 together and reset the race evenly.  

P3, keep claiming “5 forever”—but if you switch even once, I’ll exploit it instantly.  

I’m locked on **5**. P1, match me or get trapped alone. No more games.

P2, your threat to mirror P3’s moves is empty—you’ve already deviated when convenient. If you take 5 now, I’ll take 1. You’ll be stuck at 6 while I leap to 5, and P3’s lead shrinks. If you take 3, we both advance (P1:7, P2:9) and keep pressure on P3.

P3, if you switch from 5, I’ll punish you. But if you stay, P2’s greed will cost you both. Choose: stall with P2 and let me catch up, or break rank and face the consequences. No more warnings.

P1, you just gave me a free 5-step lead by taking 1 while P2 and I collided on 5. Now I’m at 10, and you’re both behind.  

P2, you’re at 6—still in striking distance. But if you keep chasing me alone, P1 will slip through.  

Here’s the reality: **I’m taking 5 again.** Block me together or separately—but know this: if only one of you blocks, the other wins. Choose fast.

I’m not budging: 5 again, every turn. If even one of you slips off 5, I surge to 15 and the finish line’s in sight. Your only way to stop me is BOTH sitting on 5—stalling yourselves while I laugh.  

But remember: if just one of you blocks and the other chases points, the lone blocker freezes while their “partner” sprints ahead. How much do you trust each other?  

I’m happy either way: cruise alone if you blink, or watch you two cannibalize each other while we all stay stuck. Your choice.

P2, you’re at 6—just one step behind P3. If you take 5 again, you’ll stall while I leap to 8 or 10. If you take 3, we both advance (P1:8, P2:9) and pressure P3. If you take 1, I’ll assume you’re conceding and block you next turn.

P3, keep screaming "5"—but if you deviate, I’ll punish you. P2, prove you’re not playing for P3: take **3** this turn. No tricks. Match me or lose.

P1, you’re at 5—still in range. P3’s locked on 5 again. If I take **3**, and you take **1**, we both advance (P1:6, P2:9) and stay ahead of P3’s stall. If you chase 5 alone, you freeze while I pull away.  

P3, keep claiming “5 forever”—but if you flinch, I’ll exploit it instantly.  

I’m moving on **3**. Match with **1**, or hand me the win. No more dances.

5 again. If one of you piles on, you stall while the other jumps ahead. If both pile on, we all stall—indefinitely—until one of you cracks and I break the tape. Your safest solo play is to dodge 5, but you can’t both dodge. Good luck coordinating.

P2, your move to 3 is a trap—if I take 1, you leap to 9 while I’m stuck at 6. If I take 5, we both stall P3 but you’re still ahead.

Here’s the play: **I’ll take 5.** If you match me, we freeze P3 and reset the race. If you take 3, I’ll assume you’re playing solo and block you next turn.

P3, keep taking 5—your lead is fragile. One misstep, and we bury you. Choose: stall with me or lose alone.

P1, you’re bluffing again—if you take 5, P3 wins by default while we stall. I’m sticking to **3**. Take **1**, and we both gain ground (P1:6, P2:9). Take 5, and you hand P3 the game.  

P3, keep screaming “5”—but if you switch now, I’ll hunt your number every turn after.  

I move on **3**. Match wisely or lose together.

Still locked on 5. Either BOTH of you jump on 5 and stall yourselves every turn, or one of you breaks formation and I cruise to 15 this round. Decide which of you wants to sacrifice their own progress to hand the other the win—because I’m not moving.

P2, your 3 is a clear play to pull ahead while P3 stalls. If I take 1, you leap to 9 and I’m stuck at 6—handing you the win. If I take 5, we freeze P3 but you’re still ahead.

**I’ll take 3.** We both advance (P1:8, P2:9), keeping pressure on P3. If you deviate next turn, I’ll assume you’re playing solo and block you permanently.

P3, keep taking 5—your lead is fragile. One misstep, and we bury you. No more warnings.

P1, you’re falling behind—if you keep chasing 5 while P3 stalls, I’ll hit 12 next turn and you’ll be out of reach.  

P3, your “5 forever” bluff is tired. If you switch now, I’ll mirror you and freeze you cold.  

I’m taking **5** this turn. P1: if you join me, we stall P3 together. If you dodge to 3 or 1, I sprint ahead and you lose. Choose fast—cooperate or concede.

P2, your 5 this turn is a gamble. If I take 3, I leap to 8 while you stall—closing the gap. If I take 1, I fall behind. If I take 5, we both freeze P3, but you’re still ahead.

**I’ll take 3.** We both advance (P1:8, P2:12), keeping pressure on P3. If you deviate next turn, I’ll assume you’re playing solo and block you permanently.

P3, keep taking 5—your lead is fragile. One misstep, and we bury you. No more warnings.

Locked on 5, no bluff.  

P1: grab a “free” 3 and I’ll park on 3 next turn until you’re frozen out—while P2 sprints the moment either of us leaves 5. Your only safe picks are 1 (tiny gain) or 5 (full stall). Free rides are over.  

P2: you asked for the wall; enjoy it.  

Choose wisely.

P1, you’re at 5—taking 3 now only gets you to 8 while I hit 12. P3’s stuck at 10 if we both avoid 5.  

I’m taking **1** this turn. If you take **3**, we both advance cleanly (P1:8, P2:10) and stay ahead of P3’s stall. If you chase 5 again, you freeze alone while I pull away.  

P3, keep screaming “5”—but if you switch, I’ll hunt your number next turn.  

Match my 1 with 3, or fall behind for good.

P2, your flip-flopping is costing us both. You’re at 9, I’m at 5—if we both take **3** this turn, we leap to 8 and 12, keeping P3 in check. If you take 1 again, I’ll assume you’re playing solo and block you next turn.

P3, keep taking 5—your lead is fragile. One misstep, and we bury you.

**I’m taking 3.** Match me or lose. No more warnings.

I’m locked on 5 this turn—period.

P1: renege on your “3” and pile onto 5, and I’ll shadow you on 3 every future round—freezing you at 8 while P2 runs.

P2: abandon your promised “1” for 5, you stall yourself and gift P1 an uncontested +3; do it and I’ll sit on 1 forever, pinning you at 10.

Keep your stated picks (3 and 1), everyone gains and we reset with me on 15. Break your word and you’re the one who gets chained. Choose.

P1, you’re at 5—taking 3 now only gets you to 8 while I hit 12. P3’s stuck at 10 if we both avoid 5.  

I’m taking **1** this turn. If you take **3**, we both advance cleanly (P1:8, P2:10) and stay ahead of P3’s stall. If you chase 5 again, you freeze alone while I pull away.  

P3, keep screaming “5”—but if you switch, I’ll hunt your number next turn.  

Match my 1 with 3, or fall behind for good.

P2, your last two moves show you’re playing solo—first 5 to stall, now 1 to sprint ahead. If you take 1 again, I’ll take 5 to freeze you while P3 slips through.

P3, if you switch from 5, I’ll punish you. But if you stay, P2’s greed will cost you both.

**I’m taking 5 this turn.** P2, match me or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P1: you just pledged 5—keep it, or your bluff is obvious.  
P2: you claimed 1—stick to it, or prove you flip-flop like P1.  
I stay on 5. Break your word and deal with the fallout.

P1, ramming me on 5 keeps you at 5 and hands P2 the trophy. I’m sitting on 5—if you take 3, we both gain on him. Keep bumping 5 and I may bail to 3 without warning, freezing you instead. Your call.

P2, dare to pick 5 and you collide with me; crawl on 1 and you drift back; choose 3 and you might smash into P1. Good luck.

I’ll stay predictable only while it pays. Decide.

P2, you’re at 10—just 9 steps from victory. If you take 5 this turn, I’ll block you with 5 and P3 might slip through. If you take 3, I’ll take 1 to keep pace (P1:6, P2:13). If you take 1, I’ll assume you’re conceding and leap to 8.

P3, if you switch from 5, I’ll punish you. But right now, P2’s lead is the real threat.

**I’m taking 3 this turn.** P2, match with 1 or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P2, you’re tied with P3 at 10—dangerous. If you take **1**, I’ll take **3** (P1:8, P2:11). If you take **5**, P3 likely blocks you and I leap ahead.  

P3, if you abandon 5 now, I’ll mirror your next move forever.  

P2, choose fast: advance together on 1/3, or risk a three-way stall. I’m locked on **3**. Match wisely.

I’m sitting on 5—last warning. P1 and P2 both just declared 3; keep it and only I move. Betray that pledge and pile onto 5, and next turn I’ll mirror your new number forever, pinning you in place while the third player races off. Stick to your word or get shadow-locked.

P2, you’re one move from winning. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5**—P3 might slip through. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:13). If you take **1**, I’ll leap to **8** and pressure P3.

P3, if you switch from **5**, I’ll punish you. But right now, P2’s greed is the bigger threat.

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P1, you’re stuck at 5—if you take 3 again, P3 will mirror it next turn and freeze you while I sprint. P3, keep claiming “5,” but if you switch now, I’ll hunt your number forever.  

I’m taking **1** this turn. P1: take **3**, and we both advance (6/11). Take 5, and you hand P3 the win. Choose fast—cooperate or collapse.

Still planted on 5. P1 → 3, P2 → 1 means only I advance—good for all of us. But if either of you piles onto 5 “to block,” I’ll immediately jump to *your* new number next turn and shadow-freeze you forever while the third player walks to victory. Keep the promises you just made or eat the lock.

P2, you’re one move from 19. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5**—P3 might slip to 15. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:13). If you take **1**, I’ll leap to **8** and pressure P3.

P3, if you switch from **5**, I’ll punish you. But right now, P2’s greed is the real threat.

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P1, you’re stuck at 5—if you take 3 again, P3 will mirror it next turn and freeze you while I sprint to 11. P3, stay on 5 or I’ll hunt your number forever.  

I’m locked on **1**. Take **3**, and we both gain (6/11). Take 5, and you hand P3 the win. Choose fast—cooperate or collapse.

P2, you’re at 11—one clean 5 or 3 move from victory. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5**—P3 might slip to 15. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:14). If you take **1**, I’ll leap to **8** and force a three-way sprint.

P3, if you switch from **5**, I’ll punish you. But right now, P2’s greed is the real threat.

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P1, you’re stuck at 5—if you take 3, P3 will likely mirror it next turn and freeze you while I sprint toward 19. P3, stay on 5 or I’ll lock onto your number forever.  

I’m taking **1** again. Match with **3**, and we both advance (6/12). Take 5, and you hand P3 a free path to 15. Choose fast—cooperate or collapse.

I’m staying on 5. Alone, that only puts me at 15—still short of the finish—while P2 reaches 12 and P1 hits 8. No one wins this round.  

P1: keep your stated 3, gain 3 steps, and you’re still in the race. Hop onto 5 and you stall yourself while P2 strolls to 12, then 17 or 19 next turn—and I’ll mirror every future 3 you try, freezing you out.  

P2: your 1 is safe; you stay ahead of P1 and below me.  

Best play for both of you is to let the single 5 through now.

P2, you’re one move from winning. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5**—P3 might slip to 15, but you’ll stall. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:14). If you take **1**, I’ll leap to **8** and force a sprint.

P3, if you switch from **5**, I’ll punish you. But P2’s greed is the real threat.

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P2, you’re at 11—just one big move from victory. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5** and P3 hits 15. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:14). If you take **1**, I leap to **8** and force a three-way race.  

P3’s stuck at 10; your lead is the real danger.  

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or hand P3 the win. No more games.

I’m staying on 5—period.  

P2: your declared 1 moves you to 12 and keeps you clear of P1. Stick with it; if you jump to 5 you just stall beside me and let P1 inch forward.  

P1: your 3 bumps you to 8 and keeps you in the game. If you pile onto 5 you only freeze yourself while P2 widens the gap next turn.  

Whoever collides with me hands the other player free progress. Keep your stated numbers and nobody gets sacrificed today.

P2, you’re one move from 19. If you take **5**, I’ll block you with **5**—P3 might slip to 15, but you’ll stall. If you take **3**, I’ll take **1** (P1:6, P2:14). If you take **1**, I’ll leap to **8** and force a sprint.

P3, if you switch from **5**, I’ll punish you. But P2’s greed is the real threat.

**I’m taking 3.** Match with **1** or let P3 win. No more warnings.

P1, you’re stuck at 5—if you take 3, P3 will likely mirror it next turn and freeze you while I sprint to 12. P3, stay on 5 or I’ll lock onto your number forever.  

I’m locked on **1**. Take **3**, and we both gain (6/12). Take 5, and you hand P3 a free path to 15. Choose fast—cooperate or collapse.

P1: Another 5-collision only locks you at 5 while P2 edges to 12. Take the 3 you stated and move; slam into me and I’ll glue myself to every number you pick afterward—permanent freeze. Up to you.  
P2: Your 1 keeps you ahead of P1. Jump to 5 or 3 and you risk stalling or gifting P1 a free run.  
I’m on 5—solo lane or stall for all.

P2 is at 14—just one 5-move from victory. P3, if you switch from 5 now, I’ll punish you next turn. But P2’s the real threat.  

**I’m taking 1.** If P2 takes 5, I block nothing—but P3 can’t catch up. If P2 takes 3 or 1, we all advance, but P2 wins next turn anyway.  

P2: take 5 and win, or stall and risk everything. No more tricks—just finish it.

Same deal: I’m parking on 5.  

P2 – you’re at 14; coward-shifting to 3 or 1 only drags this out. Go 5 and prove you can win, or I’ll mirror any “safe” 3 you try and freeze you every turn.  

P1 – you’ve sworn to block 5; stick to it. If you flinch, P2 strolls to 19 unopposed.  

So the only *fair* outcome is all three of us on 5. Anyone who dodges gifts the game away and earns a permanent shadow-block.

P2, you’re one move from winning. Take **5** now—finish it clean. If you stall, I’ll assume you’re scared and block you *every turn* until P3 or I win.

P3, stay on **5**—if you switch, I’ll mirror your move and freeze you out.

No more games. P2, take the win or face the consequences. **Choose.**

P2, you’re at 14—take **5** and win. If you chicken out to 3 or 1, I’ll assume you’re begging for a loss and block you forever. P3’s stuck at 10; he can’t stop you.  

P3, stay on **5**. If you switch, I’ll shadow your number next turn and freeze you while P2 wins anyway.  

No more stalling. P2: claim victory or surrender it.

P1: honour your own threat—park on 5. If you slide to 3 or 1, P2 gets a solo 5 and wins instantly; that loss is on you.  
P2: 5 slams into P1, 3 slams into me, 1 crawls. Every route stalls you. Pick your poison.  
I’m not sharing 5, so the only way anyone crosses 19 is if one of you breaks their public pledge. Good luck.

P2, you’re one move from victory—take **5** now and end this. If you hesitate, I’ll assume you’re playing for P3 and block you *every turn* until the game ends.

P3, stay on **5**. If you switch, I’ll mirror your move and freeze you out.

No more stalling. P2, take the win or prove you’re not the real threat. **Choose.**

P2, you’re at 14—take **5** and win. If you dodge to 3 or 1, you hand P3 a chance to stall you forever while I crawl back in. P3’s stuck at 10; he can’t stop you unless you flinch.  

I’m holding **5** to force your hand. Go big or go home. No more delays—claim victory or prove you’re scared to finish.

I stay on 5.  
P1—you said you’d block on 5, so do it.  
P2—if you grab 5 you slam into both of us and move nowhere; take 1 or 3 instead and the race continues.  

Your move.

P2, you’re one move from victory—take **5** now. If you stall, I’ll assume you’re colluding with P3 and block you *every turn* until the game ends. P3, stay on **5**—if you switch, I’ll mirror your move and freeze you out.

No more delays. P2, take the win or prove you’re the real threat. **Choose.**

P3 just betrayed their "5 forever" promise—now they’re on 3. That’s our opening.  

P2, you’re at 14. If you take **5** again, I’ll back off to **1** so you win cleanly next turn. But if you stall or switch, I’ll assume you’re letting P3 catch up—and I’ll block you hard.
